Opinion Investors must remember fast Fitbit and GoPro declines when other hardware startups hit Wall Street
Opinion Investors must remember fast Fitbit and GoPro declines when other hardware startups hit Wall Street
By
By

The recent struggles of Fitbit Inc and GoPro Inc show that stand alone niche hardware companies will invariably struggle, a lesson investors should remember next time Silicon Valley pops out a young device maker

The recent struggles of Fitbit Inc and GoPro Inc show that stand alone niche hardware companies will invariably struggle, a lesson investors should remember next time Silicon Valley pops out a young device maker

Fitbit and GoPro live in the much hyped wearable computing category with distinct target markets But in the past few months,  analysts have been warning about signs of market saturation in the core areas for both companies

Both are trying to diversify, GoPro through its drones and Fitbit with a focus on software that has led it to  acquire the assets of smartwatch makers Pebble and Vector and forge partnerships with other companies like insurance carriers that can offer value through a software ecosystem

Despite Fitbit s leading position within wearables and projected 2 70 cash share at 4Q end, slowing category growth, potential domestic saturation, and weak adoption abroad suggest declining unit demand and pressure on ASP [average selling prices] for the foreseeable future,” said Betty Chen, managing director of Mizuho Securities USA, in a note to clients
Mizuho maintained a neutral rating
“We believe lack of top-line visibility will continue to pressure the stock.”

Despite Fitbit s leading position within wearables and projected 2 70 cash share at 4Q end, slowing category growth, potential domestic saturation, and weak adoption abroad suggest declining unit demand and pressure on ASP [average selling prices] for the foreseeable future,” said Betty Chen, managing director of Mizuho Securities USA, in a note to clients
Mizuho maintained a neutral rating

The travails of Fitbit and GoPro exemplify why venture capital investors more often seek out software companies, which require far less capital to start up, can scale easier and don’t face the same manufacturing costs and complexities

Hardware aimed at consumers has even more issues, as consumers for the most part seem to be signaling that only a limited number of them will adopt these truly dedicated devices, especially when the smartphone continues to offer advanced functionality

After a pretty rotten holiday quarter action camera maker GoPro Inc is now staking its hopes for survival on making its cameras work better with phones, positioning itself for a potential bailout from a smartphone maker like Apple Inc

After a pretty rotten holiday quarter action camera maker GoPro Inc is now staking its hopes for survival on making its cameras work better with phones, positioning itself for a potential bailout from a smartphone maker like Apple Inc

GoPro founder and Chief Executive Nick Woodman said the company plans to make the smartphone central to the GoPro experience,” and development of new camera products will have “the smartphone playing an even more central role.” He would not disclose any new product plans but added that one goal is to make the smartphone “more seamless” with GoPro cameras

GoPro certainly found more room to fall after reporting worse than expected fourth quarter results on Thursday and a weak outlook for the first quarter,  with shares plunging more than 11% in late trading
GoPro, which went public at a valuation topping $3 billion and had a market cap of more than $14 billion at one point in public trading, would be worth less than $1.5 billion if that drop holds

GoPro certainly found more room to fall after reporting worse than expected fourth quarter results on Thursday and a weak outlook for the first quarter,  with shares plunging more than 11% in late trading
GoPro, which went public at a valuation topping $3 billion and had a market cap of more than $14 billion at one point in public trading, would be worth less than $1.5 billion if that drop holds
The latest decline comes despite fourth quarter revenue of 540 6 million representing the second biggest quarter in GoPro’s history
But the quarter was also one of missed opportunities
Manufacturing issues,  announced in November, led to retailers canceling marketing support of GoPro’s new products, especially its new Hero 5 camera
The latest decline comes despite fourth quarter revenue of 540 6 million representing the second biggest quarter in GoPro’s history
But the quarter was also one of missed opportunities
Manufacturing issues,  announced in November, led to retailers canceling marketing support of GoPro’s new products, especially its new Hero 5 camera
It s significant GoPro Chief Executive Nick Woodman told analysts on a conference call when asked about the impact of the issues

“We had promotional programs in place with our top retailers around the world in getting premium placement…and unfortunately, all of those retailers understandably felt inclined to remove GoPro from their promotions—namely remove Hero 5 Black from their promotions—because we could not get them enough inventory to warrant the spend that they were going to make.”

Those companies that do not really have an ecosystem and are trying to sell hardware are also really struggling as the smartphone market is slowing to crawl with Internet of Things and wearables yet to really emerge,” Windsor wrote in a note to investors earlier this week
“This is why GoPro, Under Armour, Fitbit are all in free fall.”

In GoPro s case it is trying to expand beyond the market of extreme sports enthusiasts who film their sports activities like surfing, skiing
etc., and share their videos on YouTube, and previously on GoPro’s dedicated channel
The company is trying to expand by launching a drone, called the Karma, but it bungled the launch,  releasing a product that lost its battery while in mid air
GoPro said it has fixed the problem and relaunched the Karma yesterday, in what it admits is a tough market for consumer drones

Apple or another smartphone manufacturer like Samsung Electronics Co Ltd or Lenovo Group Ltd s Motorola could conceivably solve the bulk of GoPro’s issues with software resources, manufacturing prowess, reach and GoPro’s newest problem, lack of credibility with major retailers
GoPro, meanwhile, would provide a meaningful sales bump

Despite disappointing investors, GoPro recorded $1.19 billion in revenue in 2016 and $1.6 billion in 2015, and there is potential for more with the Karma—a name Steve Jobs would have loved, by the way

Despite disappointing investors, GoPro recorded $1.19 billion in revenue in 2016 and $1.6 billion in 2015, and there is potential for more with the Karma—a name Steve Jobs would have loved, by the way
It s going to take a lot to make GoPro a stock that investors want to own again, so angling for an acquisition right now makes sense
GoPro is unlikely to get more than its IPO valuation in such a deal, but that may be a welcome outcome for those tired of watching this company stumble
